"spot the fakeness fifty yards away. During the making of 'Sweeney,' my daughter ended up in the hospital with a life threatening illness, so that affected my performance, as well. You can’t broom out your head. You certainly can’t broom out your heart...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/7vEoAYfouS
"boom guy has the microphone just inches above your eyebrows and the focus puller and the camera op­erator are right there. You have to commit yourself to the moment, b/c of the veins in your neck and your head; lip-syncing would be a lie, and people would..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/8XTgHJCB8E
"of the shot. It was very exciting to witness. And I didn’t get fired! I had expected we would lip-sync, but you can’t lip-sync. You’ve gotta belt it out, which is extra-mortifying. There’s a tiny little speaker over there playing the music and the..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/dZyZSHODES
"and Sacha |Baron Cohen]. It was a ball. With Tim, it’s a process of discovery, although he has very solid ideas before he goes in there. As much as Tim was watching me or Hel­ena, I was watching Tim with Dariusz [Wolski], the DP, finding the poetry..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/OR3E9tRvz2
"talked about the torment that this guy would’ve felt, to have his family ripped away from him. The only thing that kept his heart beating was that he could have his revenge. But on the set, we laughed like absolute fools, Tim and I, and Helena [Bonham Carter]..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/FIMzjTqWCs
"On Fear and Loathing, when I was doing scenes where I had to be tripping, I used sound effects to spin me out b/c there was no way to do the film actually being loaded. In Sweeney, my face is a rictus of pain; it's horrible. I can’t watch it. Tim and I..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/CvCiapYjov
"I can hear a song from the late Sixties, when I was a little kid, and all of a sudden you smell the room, you sense the weather outside, you hear the sound of the car tires on the gravel. Music is the fastest way to your creative source...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/7WsjwOJffu
"it becomes emotional organically. You’re not even searching for anything, and it’s already become emotional. It’s built into Sondheim’s stuff. Music had colored my performances in every film. I use music constantly. Music is in­stant emotion...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/lVkwep4kJg
"incredibly beautiful melo­dies, and what goes along with those melodies are some­times dissonant, super-complex chord arrangements that actually shouldn’t make sense. They shouldn’t go together, but they do somehow, because he’s a genius. Doing that music,..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/Ff4Tq1GjmO
"scales or arpeggios. And then you’re faced with the idea of, like, refusing: 'No, I won’t be doing that, Mr. Sondheim.' But he was great. He said it was more important to hit the emotional notes than to hit the musical notes. Sondheim has..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/U34qHcZORV
"Nobody knew if I could sing! I have no idea why he gave me his blessing. I was half-expecting, and this scared the sh*t out of me, for Stephen to say, 'Come over here, kid, let’s go by the piano.' I had this image of him ask­ing me to sing..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/RO2kcwRn7A
"production of Sweeney, which was great. That was the only time I saw the show onstage. The next day I was meeting with Stephen at his house, just to sit down and say hi. He was very gracious. But the weird thing was he didn’t know if I could sing...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/thfZy5b5WT
"That was a bugger. At one point, I was very close to passing out; I got dizzy and saw black. But that’s what Sondheim wrote, so that’s what you do. I had a formal meeting with Sondheim. I flew into New York to see the Michael Cerveris–Patti LuPone..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/UwlIvIy3BH
"Don’t be a p*ssy, you f*ckin’ hold that note. You can’t cheat. You can’t whisper. You can’t do the William Shatner thing. You just gotta belt it out. So, I really beat myself up, making sure I could hold those notes. In 'Johanna,' some are, like, twelve beats...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/NMZk97rhsZ
"And as far as I was concerned, when Stephen Sondheim writes the note and it has to be held for this many beats, you do it. I don’t care if you’re from Miramar or Kentucky or you’re an a*s and you don’t sing. It doesn’t matter...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/WtQSOHK7Wm
"Right off the bat it jumps an octave. 'I had him!' But actually, I burned through it pretty quick and had a number of options on that one. The one that was probably the most challenging was 'Johanna.' It’s such an emotional song...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/aHXIY1wRRp
"was going to look like or sound like. So it was different. I heard him sing before I heard him talk. All of the songs were particularly hard to crack. The one that I was least looking forward to singing was 'Epiphany,' b/c it’s just all over the joint...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/baR8YuF43z
"and then you tell me.' Doing the music first changed my approach to the character. It was a very different process. Because I had no idea who Sweeney was. I mean, I knew the story and I knew what other guys had done with Sweeney. But I didn’t know what my Sweeney..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/kqNCcdp1Nw
"I knew I could hit certain notes, but I didn’t know if I could hold them. I called Tim and I said, 'I think I can do it, but I’m going to go into the studio with a buddy [Bruce Witkin of The Kids] and I’m going to try it out. And I’ll send you a tape..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/vHOiUrbgCt
"I’d like to do it, but I don’t know if I can.' I started listening to it and familiariz­ing myself with the notes. And then slowly but surely, I started to sing along with it. I knew that I was musi­cal and could understand the structure and the chords...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/FUHz7j6DSG
"The beauty with Tim [Burton] is, you’re charged up when he calls you b/c you know something is going to be fun. So, we get together, and he says, 'Do you remember Sweeney Todd? Do you think you could do it?' I initially said, 'I don’t know. I mean,..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/HeCJRgzl9R
"of thing.' And then I didn’t think anything else of it. But Tim [Burton] didn’t address it again with me until five or six years later. I guess he’d been attached to it and then unattached and back and forth. And then suddenly he called...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/Yn2fo3pgn9
"'Send in the Clowns.' So, I knew of Sondheim’s work, certainly, like West Side Story, but I wasn’t familiar with Sweeney Todd until Tim gave me the CD. I listened to it and thought, 'OK, yeah, that’s interesting. But weird, b/c it’s this big operatic sort..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/AR0a609k79
"I was certainly familiar with Sondheim’s work. Jesus, he wrote 'Send in the Clowns.' Even Tom Robbins has regard for 'Send in the Clowns.' Did you ever read Fierce Invalids Home from Hot Climates? You’d love it. The main character is constantly referring to..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/NmxhdhHRMu

"There’s a lot of really funny sh*t on it. Gibby was on fire. He’s a genius. And so, after Capitol listened to the record, they just went, 'What is this?' and buried it. Which was not even the slightest disappointment." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/RYcZHioHXS
"We said, 'There will be no photographs, there will be no tour, there will be no videos, there will be no bios, there will be nothing.' And they agreed to it! We didn’t let them in the studio when we were recording the record...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/qRFyGGMwV0
to stay on key. P was a group of friends who were given the opportu­nity to make a bunch of noise together &amp; document it. For some reason, Capitol Records wanted to do it, &amp; that was the most surreal part...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/4ZIzv3JTZG
"The Oasis stuff was fun. I liked playing with those guys, &amp; I enjoyed playing slide on 'Fade In-Out.' I was playing a gui­tar that had some strange tuning, &amp; I didn’t know the chords to the song. So, looking back, it was sort of miraculous that I was able...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/OVzpUZ9K2I
15 minutes if somebody will let you. You get this feedback; you’ll bend it &amp; stretch it. I got these weird, tonal, harmonic kind of spacey things. I think the credit Shane gave me on the record was weird guitar noises by Johnny Depp....'" #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/9jcQELuG7M
"And Shane was just like, 'Arrrarrah, play some more.' So, I thought, 'Well, if I just start making some random noises.' And then you get a note that sustains, &amp; you can feel that it’s gonna hang in there, so like any guitar player, you’ll deal with it for..." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/nooxGaVC8f
"I pick up the guitar &amp; space out &amp; drool. Occasionally, I knock out a guitar solo for friends like Shane MacGowan &amp; Oasis. Playing on Shane’s record was...there are snippets of memory. The song seemed like it was fine, it didn’t need anything else...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/f6oIqFSAbX
"Music will always be my first love. But if I continued to do it for a living, I don’t know that I would feel the same way about it. I’m glad that it worked out this way, b/c it’s still as fresh as it was back then, and I’m not pressured to write hit songs...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/CnhfkuDZGa
"I never wanted to be an actor. It just seemed like a good way to make easy money. I didn’t care what the movies were. If you’re going to pay me, fine. That was my philosophy. Looking back, I don't regret not ending up a musician instead of an actor...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/LP2EAssPBr
"It was scale, $1,200 a week for eight weeks, which was absolutely ludicrous. That’s mad money! So, I said to the band, 'I’m gonna do this thing, it’s eight weeks, &amp; then I’ll come back.' But it didn’t work that way. Everybody went in their own di­rection...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/rLPLBJKN3k
"And Nic said, 'Why don’t you try acting? I think you could probably do it.' I remem­ber saying, 'I’ll try anything, man.' I gotta live w/out calling home &amp; begging for money. So, I met his agent, &amp; she sent me to read for Nightmare on Elm Street, &amp; they hired me...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/rAnlKAQsf4
"I’m a thief; we’re ripping you off.' So, I wasn’t good at it. The Kids were struggling. Everybody started getting nervous &amp; weird. I was filling out job applications for video stores on Melrose. Nicolas Cage was with me, and we got along pretty well...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/glEaZlLzf4
"The couple of times that I actually got people to buy the pens, they only agreed because they wanted the grandfather clock. And when the supervisor wandered off, I would say, 'Listen, don’t buy these pens. The clock is made of corkboard...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/9dhBjAVp4Q
"Oddly, that’s kind of my first experience with acting. You’re reading a whole spiel. There was a character on the soap opera General Hospital &amp; the name stuck in my head, so I would call people up and say, 'How do you do, this is Edward Quartermaine....'" #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/TVKLycIVnw
"We have to eat, so we end up getting jobs. I paid the rent doing phone sales. Me &amp; a couple of the other guys in the band sold ink pens over the telephone. You’d guarantee them a grandfather clock or a trip to Greece...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/LxbPdMgjBT
"We needed a challenge, &amp; the best challenge in the world was 'Let’s go to LA and see if we can get signed.' In '83, we packed up these U-Haul trailers &amp; set out for LA. But suddenly we’re not big fish in a little pond, we’re guppies &amp; we’re nearly destitute...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/8LcgUFDbTo
"Our main influences were Elvis Costello, the Clash &amp; early Motown stuff, especially the Jackson 5. And U2. They were just coming up when we played 'I Will Follow;' people used to think it was our song. Eventually, we left Florida...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/KWgTzmUt0y
"And when I was sev­enteen, this band called The Kids needed a guitar player, &amp; I joined them. It was a very solid band. And the opportunities we had were incredible. We played huge shows, open­ing for the Ramones, the Pretenders, Iggy Pop, Stray Cats...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/nJyXo3bBYH
"You love your mu­sic, that’s the only thing you’ve ever applied yourself to. Go out there and play.' He wasn’t nasty about it; he was giving me good advice. Then I was in a band called — very original — Bad Boys...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/qs8Id82XCM
"I was teetering. But then I had a realization: I’ve only been out of school two weeks. I can go back. So, I sat down with the dean &amp; said, 'Listen, I made a mistake &amp; I’d like to try again.' And bless him, he said, 'Johnny, I don’t think that’s such a good idea...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/Z4w9CgGZrF
"About sixteen. I was playing clubs, but suddenly I had made the choice to become an adult. My parents said, 'OK, kid, you’ve taken yourself out of school, so you fend for yourself.' So, there weren’t many options. I was very close to joining the Marine Corps...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/4Oqt9o7Zmv
"I didn’t want to be that guy at all. Plus, singers had to do stuff that I found mortifying, like jump around. Horror show. I just liked playing very loud &amp; keeping my head down, staying in the dark...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/YwjYCuwfOn
"You start out with super-innocent names like Flame, &amp; by the time you’re fifteen, you’re the guitar­ist in a band called B*tch. I never wanted to be a singer.  I didn’t want to be the guy that everybody looked at. It's ironic in hindsight...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/YBCBqXlYVZ
"You’re thirteen years old &amp; you’re playing rock &amp; roll. Loud. Poorly. But somebody’s letting you do it in their backyard. And it was absolute perfection. It was freedom. Right off the bat, there was no question: I had found my future...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/z77V9KFOH9
"This one guy had a bass, we knew a guy who had a PA system, we made our own lights. It was really ramshackle &amp; great. We’d play at people’s backyard parties. Everything from the Beatles to Led Zeppelin to Cheap Trick to Devo and 'Johnny B. Goode' was the closer...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/ET7cSd5P3q
"But the first song I played all the way through must have been 'Stairway to Heaven.' I remember getting through the fingerpicking &amp; just cursing Jimmy Page. When I was about thirteen, I got together with some other kids in the neighborhood...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/igQW298oj2
"I locked the bedroom door, didn’t leave, &amp; taught myself how to play chords. I started learning songs by ear. Every kid with a guitar at that time, the first things that came up were almost always 'Smoke on the Water,' obviously, &amp; '25 or 6 to 4,' by Chicago...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/pSLOpzazx1
"I went to this store, stuffed it down my pants &amp; walked out. It had pictures, that’s why I needed it so badly, b/c it was immediate gratification. If I could match those photographs, then I was golden. I conquered it in days...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/aFwvQcLdGj
"When I was twelve, I talked my mom into picking up a Decca electric guitar for me for twenty-five dollars. It had a little blue plush amp. And then, this is horrible, the first thing I did was steal a Mel Bay chord book...." #JohnnyDepp https://t.co/7FcCrqYA08

"Basquiat was, and is music... primitive &amp; ferocious." #JohnnyDepp 

Basquiat Art Exhibition Catalog, Paris, 2003
Nothing can replace the warmth &amp; immediacy of Basquiat's poetry, or the absolute questions &amp; truths that he delivered. The beautiful &amp; disturbing music of his paintings, the cacophony of his silence that attacks our senses, will live far beyond our breath." #JohnnyDepp
"hammer of censorship slamming him hard. Had Jean-Michel Basquiat lived through the fatal times that eventually took him away from this world, there's no telling what he would've been able to do. The possibilities are endless." #JohnnyDepp
"but one that would have opened the floodgates for his messages to attack the masses. Something akin to Lenny Bruce's 'Thank You Mask Man,' an ingenious weapon that enabled him to scatter his divine tirades out into the world without the..." #JohnnyDepp
"&amp; if Jean-Michel Basquiat had stuck around for a bit longer, I like to think that he might have eventually moved into animation, for a time at least, combining his music, his language &amp; drawings into an arena seemingly more palatable to the rank &amp; file,..." #JohnnyDepp
"appears to have been executed, every line, mark, scratch, drip, footprint, fingerprint, word, letter, rip &amp; imperfection is there b/c he allowed it to be there. His paintings &amp; drawings come alive for me every time I look at them,..." #JohnnyDepp
"draw upon for his chaotic assaults. Looking at these works, one cannot escape without feeling the almost perverse sense of care taken to raw detail w/ what seems an acute distracted concentration. However crude the image may be or how fast it..." #JohnnyDepp
"He sometimes even used the drawings of his friend's children as inspirations. His deep understanding &amp; profound confusion w/ the American culture that he practically drowned himself in, was also an infinite reservoir from which he could..." #JohnnyDepp
"He was never truly able to hide his feelings or influence in the work. He openly acknowledged Cy Twombly, Picasso, the word juxtaposition of William Burroughs &amp; Brian Gyson, Andy Warhol, Leonardo da Vinci, Be Bop Jazz, TV programs &amp; cartoons." #JohnnyDepp
"his childhood heroes Hank Aaron &amp; Charlie Parker, etc., sainted for all eternity, the homage to his ancestry, endless references to his childhood...he splayed himself open like a can of sardines for all of us to pick at, as he, in fact, devoured us." #JohnnyDepp
"As did his heartfelt disappointments in the human race, &amp; his hopes for it. The signature imagery that comes to mind: the crown, the halo of thorns, portraits stripped of flesh, vital organs pumping blood- blue veined or devoid of any life,..." #JohnnyDepp
"that he spewed into his drawings, paintings, objects, writings, whatever, he had a killer sense of humor. Even in some of his most poignant works, his devilish sense of the absurd came through like gangbusters, completely unfiltered." #JohnnyDepp
"absolutely nothing for me. But once you are touched by him, you are burned into either a kind of emotional stillness, or you may find yourself on the verge of doubling over into a painful belly laugh. Because as much honesty &amp; history &amp; life experience..." #JohnnyDepp
"the many jaded, &amp; therefore ruined, intellectual art-hag &amp; simpleton alike. That is the objective. It is a game of hit or miss. And when this motherf*cker hits, he hits hard, on many levels. There are some of his works that kill me &amp; some that do..." #JohnnyDepp
"One either loves w/ a passion or despises w/ a vengeance. I've never heard of anyone saying, 'Well, he's okay, I guess.' No, to my knowledge, that doesn't happen w/ Basquiat. This is a very difficult result to achieve in any art form." #JohnnyDepp
"his art inseparable, an unholy bond merging the two into one. If we really get down to brass tacks here, we can begin by saying that Basquiat is not for everyone. Much like pork is not for everyone. You either get it, or you don't." #JohnnyDepp
"moment when he connected w/ his target. Early drawings show that he even literally shed his own blood onto the paper as proof of his commitment to the piece, his art, an acceptance of his destiny. A blood fusion, like a voodoo ritual, making the man &amp;..." #JohnnyDepp
"impossible to speak about his works without it becoming a crude dissection of the man. On any canvas or drawing, he spilled himself, maybe even without wanting to. His thoughts, his feelings, however fleeting, unfinished or incomplete are captured in that..." #JohnnyDepp
"I didn't know the guy &amp; had never met him, so the only thing that I really have is my opinion &amp; my take on the legacy of what he left behind in art. That, &amp; of course, we seemed to share the same affinity for pork products. However, it is almost..." #JohnnyDepp
"was about to republish. He said that if I wrote the piece, I should, at all costs, try to avoid writing about Basquiat's life. Everyone, it seems, has a tendency to write more about the man than the work itself. This seemed fair enough, especially since..." #JohnnyDepp
"any man to the nearest carnival-like market &amp; throw down all of his coin for as much pork as humanly possible. So we did just that. Between bites, Enrico brought up the idea of me writing something for the new &amp; updated big book of Basquiat paintings he..." #JohnnyDepp
"The brain has been fed well that day, having just seen a collection of Jean-Michel Basquiat's works &amp; then on to another museum for a quick peak at a huge Warhol exhibition. All this information, in the matter of a few hours, is enough stimulation to drive..." #JohnnyDepp
"24 hours since any solid had slithered down my gullet &amp; my appetite was ravenous. And now, here we were, bearing down on this greasy pig meat &amp; all too grateful for it, even as the plane dipped &amp; jilted us around like kewpee dolls." #JohnnyDepp
"an enormous Austrian pork hock, at least we hoped it was. We'd acquired the beast at a small, run down, carnival-like market on the edge of Vienna. Our feast was primitive &amp; ferocious. Speaking for myself, I can honestly say that it had been at least..." #JohnnyDepp
"On a turbulent flight out of Vienna, enroute to Paris, I was asked to write a couple of pages about the works of Jean-Michel Basquiat. The passengers on this bumpy journey-Enrico Navarra, Sebastian Moreu, &amp; myself were in the throes of what happened to be..." #JohnnyDepp
